> 
> Yes. But I have to point out that www.mysite.com is not the same as
> my backend rest.mysite.com. The www site has no database in it. It is
> a simple system that just transforms ATOM feeds exactly like you
> describe. I don't want the www site to return anything but HTML. If
> someone wants the ATOM feed, I'll give them the backend REST resource
> URL.
> 

If someone wants the Atom feed, they can find it by looking for a link
rel='alternate' with type='application/atom+xml' (you may also use this
link relation to load a source file, instead of rel='source').  Browsers
tend to do this automatically these days, and display an icon for feed
subscription.

If a request comes to www.mysite.com, presumably the default is to
serve an index.html file.  However, if the request only has Accept:
application/atom+xml, you have three options.  First, a 404 response.
Second and third, conneg.

You can serve the Atom source as a 200 response with a Content-Location
header pointing to the rest.mysite.com backend.  Or you can respond
with a 301 redirect with a Location header pointing to the rest.mysite.
com backend.  This "a priori" knowledge on the server's part does not
constitute coupling.

-Eric
